historicalDescription: This area in the Dorsoduro sestiere was known for a convent of hermit nuns located nearby in the 15th century. The fondamenta (quay) likely took its name from this religious establishment.

connection.historicalDescription: Named after the convent of the Eremite (Hermit Nuns) that was located in this area during the Renaissance period. The Eremite were a female religious order who followed strict rules of seclusion and prayer. The fondamenta (waterside walkway) takes its name from this same convent, and the bridge would have been a crucial access point to the religious complex.

buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the Augustinian hermit nuns who maintained a convent near the Fondamenta de le Eremite during the 15th-16th centuries. These secluded religious women were known for their strict observance of isolation and prayer.

This street was originally a small canal that was filled in (rio terà) during the 16th century. It led to the cloister of the hermit nuns' convent, serving as an important access point for supplies and occasional visitors to the secluded religious community.

This covered passageway references the manuscript production that took place in the convent near Fondamenta de le Eremite. The nuns were known to create religious manuscripts and prayer books, using pergamena (parchment) for important religious texts.

Located near the waterfront where rope makers (cordai) would craft special cords that were blessed by the hermit nuns for use on Venetian ships. These blessed ropes were believed to provide protection during sea voyages and were highly valued by Venetian merchants and sailors.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Paved Street of the Donà Family
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the noble Donà family who were patrons of the hermit nuns' convent in the 16th century. The Donà were a prominent Venetian nobili family who funded the paving of this street (hence 'salizada', meaning paved) and contributed significantly to the convent's maintenance and expansion.
